content.text: A **proof** demonstrates that a conclusion follows necessarily from premises. In natural deduction, we build proofs step by step, applying inference rules until we reach our goal.

content.definition: A proof that proceeds directly from premises to conclusion using inference rules, without assuming the negation of what we want to prove.

content.text: The simplest proofs use basic rules like **Modus Ponens** (from P and P → Q, infer Q) and **conjunction elimination** (from P ∧ Q, infer P or Q).

content.title: A Simple Proof
content.conclusion: Therefore: P → Q, Q → R, P ⊢ R
content.note: Each step follows from previous lines by a stated rule.

content.text: Always state which rule you're using and which lines it applies to. This makes your proof checkable — anyone can verify each step is valid.
Strategy tip: Work backwards from your goal. Ask 'What would give me this conclusion?' Then try to derive that from what you have.

content.question: What is Modus Ponens?
options: From P and P → Q, infer Q
From P ∨ Q and ¬P, infer Q
content.explanation: Modus Ponens (MP) says: if you have P and P → Q, you can conclude Q. It's the most basic rule for using conditionals.
